This is basic heat and mass transfer, low level chemical engineering shit. Problem is that *neither* the topology of the heat production and conduction through solid components, *nor* the convection and boundary rates are well defined and if they were it would only be for a specific case with a specific geometry. The 'magic' is going to be a hyperspecific derived set of gradients or a very fucking rough empirical constant. Did it in school and for 3D models, and they are still not that great and never approximate steady state anyway.

Also temperature is not linear, it is a fundamental thermodynamic property (not that it matters but it annoys me)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First, read a textbook about programming in some language, then manuals for several programming languages including Lisp. If they make natural intuitive sense to you, that indicates your mind is well-adapted towards programming.

If they don't make intuitive sense to you, I suggest you do something other than programming. You might be able to do programming to some degree with a struggle, but if you find it a struggle you won't be very good at it and you won't enjoy it. What's the point of programming if it is a struggle instead of a fascination?

After that, you need to read the source code of real programs (or parts of them) and figure out what they do. Then start writing changes in them, to add features, or fix bugs if you can find out about specific bugs to fix. Ask some good programmers who are familiar with the code of those programs to read and critique your changes.

If you fix bugs in a free program that others are developing, the developers are likely to be glad to get fixes from you and will tell you the way to write them to make them good to install. Look at their TODO list for features they would like to add, and implement some. You will find it is a great satisfaction when the developers incorporate your changes.

Do this over and over and you will become good at developing software.

Please use your programming capability only for good, not for evil. Don't develop nonfree software, or Service as a Software Substitute. Design systems not to collect personal information, and to allow anonymous use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91257770
Speakers on a phone don't matter. Use earphones. If it's something to share and the stock speakers aren't enough, likely you can use an aux or bt to connect to proper speakers. Cameras on a phone don't actually matter. as long as they don't take potato pics it's good enough. There are bottlenecks to how good it can look purely on lens size alone which requires a proper camera. You don't need any fancy camera features on a phone. Gaming also isn't important and stupid to care about on a phone because demanding higher performance will disintegrate the battery and fry the motherboard. If you run it at lower specs it's fine. Caring about 'performance' on a phone is stupid. RAM size and multitask on a screen that size is also stupid. Since you can just close background apps and reopen when you need them. 6GB is well enough and anything beyond 8GB is excessive and won't be used without serious negligence. Get a laptop or at least a tablet. Screen on the phone doesn't matter too much. 60hz was the standard for over a decade and people were fine with it. You don 't need 120hz just for 'I'M GONNA SCROOL!'. OLED is nifty and helps power saving but if you're primarily consuming visual content on your phone, you're doing it wrong. Use a bigger screen at a longer distance.

I understand nobody gives a shit but.
I got a Redmi pro note 10 (8/128) last week to replace my almost 7 years old Redmi Note Pro(leo).
Couldnt be happier, game is fast as a fucking rocket the battery charges in an instant and lasts fucking forever.
Used the debloater in github to remove the most egregious shit and was able to uninstall most of the other shit, right now there is only a couple apps that i still have to replace but other than those im super happy with MIUI right now, might end up updating to a custom rom at some point.
The only lacking part of the phone is not having a notification led near the camera, i was used to it on my previous phone to know at a glance if i had any missed call/msg/email and im missing that feature.
So yeah i guess that im comparing it against a 7 years old phone so everything would look great but i have to say it has surpassed what i expected from the 200€ i spent.
A post about somebody being happy with their phone for a change :)

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>>91257538
I use a Dell PERC H310, which as far as I'm aware is some LSI rebrand. Long story short, I switched mobos in my server and the thing stopped booting entirely, which I tracked down to the HBA, as in the server booted fine without it. After looking into it, the solution was to tape over a few pins on the PCIe slot, which apparently were carrying SMbus signals.

These cards are fairly old and apparently the use of this SMbus wasn't entirely standardized and some modern mobos take issue with it and do not work. If you just disconnect those pins, the mobo boots fine and the card works perfectly as well. I don't know whether this could cause the card itself to not work, but in any case if you're using old HBAs it's good to know.

>>91263756
>https://github.com/neonbjb/DL-Art-School
Deep Learning Art School
This repository is both a framework and a set of tools for training deep neural networks that create images. It started as a branch of the open-mmlab project developed by Multimedia Laboratory, CUHK but has been almost completely re-written at every level.
Why do we need another training framework

These are a dime a dozen, no doubt. DL Art School (DLAS) differentiates itself by being configuration driven. You write the model code (specifically, a torch.nn.Module) and (possibly) some losses, then you cobble together a config file written in yaml that tells DLAS how to train it. Swapping model architectures and tuning hyper-parameters is simple and often requires no changes to actual code. You also don't need to remember complex command line incantations. This effectively enables you to run multiple concurrent experiments that use the same codebase, as well as retain backwards compatibility for past experiments.

Training effective generators often means juggling multiple loss functions. As a result, DLAS' configuration language is specifically designed to make it easy to support large number of losses and networks that interact with each other. As an example: some GANs I have trained in this framework consist of more than 15 losses and use 2 separate discriminators and require no bespoke code.

Generators are also notorious GPU memory hogs. I have spent substantial time streamlining the training framework to support gradient checkpointing and FP16. DLAS also supports "mega batching", where multiple forward passes contribute to a single backward pass. Most models can be trained on midrange GPUs with 8-11GB of memory.

Modeling Capabilities
DLAS was built with extensibility in mind. One of the reasons I'm putting in the effort to better document this code is the incredible ease with which I have been able to train entirely new model types with no changes to the core training code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91263886
Deep Learning Art School (Model trainer for tortoise TTS)
Dependencies and Installation
Python 3
PyTorch >= 1.6
NVIDIA GPU + CUDA
Python packages: pip install -r requirements.txt
Some video utilities require FFMPEG

Development Environment
If you aren't already using Pycharm - now is the time to try it out. This project was built in Pycharm and comes with an IDEA project for you to get started with. I've done all of my development on this repo in this IDE and lean heavily on its incredible debugger. It's free. Try it out. You won't be sorry.

Dataset Preparation
DLAS comes with some Dataset instances that I have created for my own use. Unless you want to use one of the recipes above, you'll need to provide your own. Here is how to add your own Dataset:

Create a Dataset in codes/data/ which takes a single Python dict as a constructor and extracts options from that dict.
Register your Dataset in codes/data/init.py
Your Dataset should return a dict of tensors. The keys of the dict are injected directly into the training state, which you can interact within your configuration file.

Training and Testing
There are currently 3 base scripts for interacting with models. They all take a single parameter, -opt which specifies the configuration file which controls how they work. Configs (will be) documented above in the user guide.
train.py

Start (or continue) a training session: python train.py -opt <your_config.yml>

Start a distributed training session: python -m torch.distributed.launch --nproc_per_node=<gpus> --master_port=1234 train.py -o <opt> --launcher=pytorch

test.py
Runs a model against a validation or test set of data and reports metrics (for now, just PSNR and a custom perceptual metric) python test.py -opt <your_config.yml>

process_video.py
Breaks a video into individual frames and uses a network to do processing on it, then reassembles the output back into video form. python process_video -opt <your_config.yml>

>>91264808
Additionally, I would certainly look to improve upon the replicability and input flexibility. The biggest weaknesses of Elevenlabs IMO were the lack of consistency (no seed) and inability to really shape the dialogue. Of course ideally a perfect AI should know EXACTLY where to emphasize the words, but we're not there yet. If Elevenlabs allowed you autistically control the stress, spacing, tone, etc of each phoneme even the general model would be much more powerful. I haven't used the others TTS models (15ai) but I heard they were better in that regard. Something like StableDiffusions () [] and : emphasis tokens.

But you also don't want to get too bogged down in such flexibility because while I could add a ton of negatives and tokens in StableDiffusion to get a good result, I could also just type in "Epic fantasy castle in Ghibli style" into MidJourney and get a near-perfect result. The ideal is a blend between the two, but this is pie-in-the-sky thinking for a group of anons trying to figure things out.

>>91264802
>there's also a ton of stuff that you would want for coom purposes that is highly unlikely to be in any academic datasets anytime soon
I'm sure some of the more degenerate parts of the various chans have torrents for recordings of JOI/lewd audio of XJ-9 sitting on my face/etc...

there are a shit-ton of audio recordings floating around, but very few of them are actually clean. cleaning the data will be a challenge, but here is what I'm envisioning:
a data quality pipeline that's essentially a cascade of filters. each filter will run a check:
>(some trivial checks based on file type, recording length, encoding, metadata if present, etc...)
>is the audio quality high? (https://interviewfor.red/en/spectrals.html)
>does is have background noise?
>etc
>...
If the audio recording passes ALL of these automated checks, then we send it to a neetchad for manual review for the presence of background noise or other garbage. If neetchad gives us the thumbs up, ONLY then do we run whisper and give said transcript for a neetchad to review again. the whole idea here is that time is the most valuable resource and we should do everything we can to only deliver good candidate recordings to neetchads for manual reviews. data quality is a very hard problem so we should treat it as a first-class citizen here.

1/2

here's my idea for the "does is have background noise?" filter:
run each recording through a background removal program (like https://github.com/Anjok07/ultimatevocalremovergui/releases/tag/v5.5.0) . we'll discard the "vocal stem" track the program spits out and we'll run a check on the "background stem" track. if the "background stem" noise level exceeds a certain threshold, we reject the original track as it has background noise. the reason we don't keep the "vocal stem" is that these voice removal programs will usually fuck with the quality of the voice. I'm just spitballing here, we can flesh out the details down the road

at some point someone should spin up a design doc so we can sketch out what everything looks like at a high level and we can review the architecture collectively

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2104.00436.pdf

Using a style-tagged TTS dataset and a pre-
trained language model, we modeled the relationship between linguistic embedding and speaking style domain, which enables our model to work even with style tags unseen during training. As style tag is written in natural language, it can control speaking style in a more intuitive, interpretable, and scalable
way compared with style index or reference speech. In addition, in terms of model architecture, we propose an efficient non-
autoregressive (NAR) TTS architecture with single-stage training. The experimental result shows that ST-TTS outperforms the existing expressive TTS model, Tacotron2-GST in speech quality and expressiveness.

This is definitely a start anons.

posts.com:
>>91267043
Published: 04 December 2021
Text-to-speech system for low-resource language using cross-lingual transfer learning and data augmentation
Abstract
Deep learning techniques are currently being applied in automated text-to-speech (TTS) systems, resulting in significant improvements in performance. However, these methods require large amounts of text-speech paired data for model training, and collecting this data is costly. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a single-speaker TTS system containing both a spectrogram prediction network and a neural vocoder for the target language, using only 30 min of target language text-speech paired data for training. We evaluate three approaches for training the spectrogram prediction models of our TTS system, which produce mel-spectrograms from the input phoneme sequence: (1) cross-lingual transfer learning, (2) data augmentation, and (3) a combination of the previous two methods. We found that using both cross-lingual transfer learning and augmented data during training resulted in the most natural synthesized target speech output. We also compare single-speaker and multi-speaker training methods, using sequential and simultaneous training, respectively. The multi-speaker models were found to be more effective for constructing a single-speaker, low-resource TTS model. In addition, we trained two Parallel WaveGAN (PWG) neural vocoders, one using 13 h of our augmented data with 30 min of target language data and one using the entire 12 h of the original target language dataset. Our subjective AB preference test indicated that the neural vocoder trained with augmented data achieved almost the same perceived speech quality as the vocoder trained with the entire target language dataset. Overall, we found that our proposed TTS system consisting of a spectrogram prediction network and a PWG neural vocoder was able to achieve reasonable performance using only 30 min of target language training data.

posts.com:
>>91266888
Sort of, but it still holds true. Midjourney absolutely destroys StableDiffusion out-of-the-box, especially now that they have their NijiJourney anime model blended in. It's not even a close contest. Of course I'm talking about the actual models behind-the-scenes. The public-facing Midjourney can't do porn or upscale at insanely high resolutions, but that's because it's closed-source running on their servers designed to handle tens of thousands of users. Those same users are training the model in real time by selecting the best out of the 4 images they're presented. To say MidJourney is 10x better than base SD would be an understatement and I'm not trying to shill. I'm trying to emphasize the point that centralized models like MidJourney have an edge over locally hosted ones like SD and how local can still compete.

Midjourney can understand what you want and give you exactly that. "dvd screengrab, Gimli, Lord of the Rings, Studio Ghibli". Typing the same prompt into SD would give you absolute garbage. However you can likely get a similar result if you train a LOTR and Ghibli LoRA and describe the scene in detail. Our AI doesn't need to be perfect as long as users can expand it and adjust every little detail if they want to. However it can't be shit either and needs to be definitively better than 15ai and Tortoise or else it's all pointless.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91233291
>>91233432
Actually what you are experiencing is not static but a deprecation of the signal. This is due to the fact that the file size allowed to insert on a call hold system is minimal and there is the need to compress the audio file in order to allow it to be saved.
Add to that that the system also has to load the file so compression/file size does matter.
The more compression, the smaller the data file is, the less quality you have.
What you describe as static are, in reality, missing frequencies on the audible spectrum due to the compression process that, by default, cuts on the top and low frequencies to achieve it's compression results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91233003
It's gone. There are two ways you can recover files: First, the files are often still in the NTFS file table, but marked as deleted - in this case you have the filenames. Later, the files might still be on the HDD (complete or partially) when the space hasn't been overwritten already. Now you need to recognize the files based on typical file formats and they no longer have their filename.
On a TRIM enabled SSD, files vanish quickly. The space where deleted files resided is reported to the SSD so it knows these areas are no longer needed. This is useful on SSDs since they internally manage the memory, the same block on the drive is saved somewhere else anyway. It is useful for the SSD to know which of those mapped memory areas are no longer needed. So the SSD doesn't wait until the same block will be written, it can get rid of the deleted data earlier whenever it does wear leveling, garbage collection or whatever else it internally does.

You need to get decent knowledge about how servers and video streaming in general works. There are hundreds of ways to stream and deliver video in a website. If yt-dlp can't handle it, then you have to drop into your browser's devtools and check how is the video itself being delivered to your browser in the network tab. In most cases, it is just an m3u8 playlist or a simple mp4 file, which are piss easy to handle. If it is an m3u8 playlist, you can just drop the playlist URL (not the fragments, the playlist file or URL is usually playlist.m3u8, the first file downloaded when the stream is starting to play) into ffmpeg or mpv and they will handle it just fine. However, if it is dash or anything propietary, you are in for a bad time and will have to spend time reverse engineering. Matters become more complicated when the stream requires authentication or has some sort of security check.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91245468
>the traditional type of VPN that you torrent etc from
That's actually a very fucked up application for tunneling traffic. The normal and traditional use case is to tunnel individual networks, not the hacky way of routing entire Internet thru a separate endpoint.
Now that you are into tunneling to your home network, make sure its addressing differs from everybody else. Basically: pick an obscure subnetting such as 10.200.30.0/24 instead of the usual 192.168.1.0/24. What goes for IPv6: pick a net from fc::/8 such as fc00:abcd:beef::/64.
Unless you want to tunnel to nothing but the VPN server itself, then your home network addressing doesn't matter.

When you download copyrighted stuff everyone can see your IP address including copyright agencies, they just need to lurk the torrent and wait for you to join. They would then report you to your ISP or pressure them to hand out your name. The VPN fixes this because you go through their server, publicly other users will see the VPN's IP address and not yours. And while there are bad VPNs that just hand out your name, the VPNs that get recommended will not do that for torrenting a movie or album. If you are in a country where your provider wont do anything in the first place then you don't need to go through the VPN.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91239453
The trick is to start with a "thing". A "thing" can be either a key gameplay element or a rendering trick or other gimmick. Once you have the "thing" down, the game kinda writes itself so long as you can manage things like art assets, if applicable. The process is to first focus on just the "thing": play with it, iterate on it, and ideas will just kinda pop as you do that. Implement a few and bam, you have a game. Since it starts from the bottom (the "thing" comes first), it also minimizes bloat (you write code to support this, rather than writing kitchensink code and then getting to work, for example).

The game will be about space marines on mars (not doom obviously).

It is found out that mars contains a ludicrous amount of oils. The american government has set up bases all over mars to harvest it. But what they didn't anticipate was that some of the oil is actually a living infectious creature. Now mars has been thrown into chaos. Oil infected marines and mars native fauna are killing everyone.

The player (and possibly some other players) is on mars when the oil outbreak happens. The player commands an army of marines they collect as they go around mars. They use the marines to clear abandoned facilities / alien nests and fortify/defend them or loot all their resources. They can also use the marines to create stations to collect oils, water, iron and other minerals from the ground.

The goal is to secure as much oil as possible, and also to save the marines of course.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91239453
>how can we start?
Install unity and make a prototype first to see if it's even fun.
Then start adding content gradually to make sure the game is consistent and still fun.
Then start working on assets and look and feel.
Only then you start optimizing and "removing bloat" if there is any(pro tip: 99% chance if you aren't a pajeet, the game will already be optimized enough so no further debloating is needed).

If you want to make a game then focus on making a game. The language, engine, framework doesn't matter, only making the game matters. You should focus on the gameplay first, look&feel second, and only worry about implementation details if they directly conflict with the first two. This is crucial if you ever want to finish the game.

posts.com:
>>91251978
the problem with MMORPGs is that everything about them is the opposite of the strengths that indie developers have over a large game company and an indie will only ever succeed if they lean into their strengths

MMORPGs need:
a ton of content
a ton of engineering
a robust, expensive backend
a large playerbase which needs to be marketed to
a robust support structure

indies are good at:
producing a small amount of high quality content
getting the most out of a single good game mechanic
using procedural generation in clever spots to increase the amount of content

you will never ever succeed as an indie unless you know your strengths and emphasize them

>>91252050
There's no accounting for terrible taste and mmorpgs are indeed psychologically addictive. They have also been big money-makers, or at least believed to have very high potential for large profits. So there have been a lot of attempts to make new MMORPGs, high-stakes AAA games with big marketing budgets that you are likely to hear about (eg New World).

But MMORPG gameplay is usually not very good. There are systemic/design and technical problems that plague the genre as well as a relative lack of creativity. As someone who has been interested in MMORPGs since the 90s, I really think these problems are intractable. At a certain ("massive") scale there are always sociopaths. You have to design your social game around the sociopathic behavior which limits what you can do. Even without the sociopaths, social systems can evolve away from an enjoyable experience. And that's before you even consider pay2win monetization strategies that ruin the gameplay even harder.

>>91251798
Agreed. The term "souls-like" has become almost meaningless at this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91267005
the game engine is the software that sits between the computer and the game logic, typically a higher level scripted language
it has nothing to do with whether a game is 3D, 2D, text, voxel, or whatever
i guess you could say a game has no engine when it's design is so fixed-function that the product can be modded into another game without doing major changes to the machine code of the game
many games that start off with custom engines never intend the engine to be used for anything else, they may not even name the engine independent of the game
for example doom, or half-life, their engines didn't have names to begin with (half-life's engine was retroactively named goldsrc to differentiate it when valve made source, their next-gen engine), yet those games were modded into entirely different games, the code that was common among them is what is called the engine, the engine isn't a game by itself, but the vehicle that carries the game

I like the idea of Cpp2, but I'm not sure that it will ever materialize. It will be extremely hard to convince the committee to adopt something so radical.

Of course, is still possible to pursue this project outside the standards track, but then you have to convince the compiler authors to implement it, otherwise we will be stuck with a shitty preprocessor. I don't think anyone wants that, it would make the ecosystem situation even worse.

Also, the current implementation is in still in very early stages (I believe there's still no OOP support) with a non-commercial-use-only license. Even in the best case, Cpp2 is still *years* from being something usable while Rust is eating C++'s lunch.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91253101
It's the truth. This really isn't rocket science. If I index out of bounds in C I touch random memory, if I index out of bounds in Rust there's a bounds check that aborts the program instead. (In C++ you get to choose.) You can try this at home.
Use-after-free isn't that much more subtle. A careless programmer will see them all the time in C and C++, notice them happening because the program blows up or the sanitizer complains, but not in Rust (because the compiler will complain instead, before you ever run your program). Compiler and library bugs can let them slip through once in a blue moon, it's not 100% airtight, but these problems are necessarily rare—a problem that isn't rare could be noticed quickly, and unlike in C or C++ it would be considered a compiler/library bug instead of a programmer mistake.
These two problems didn't take fifty years to be discovered either, they were well-known (and sometimes had solutions!) long before C came along.
Rust is by now in use in some very valuable targets, notably Android's bluetooth stack, Firefox's rendering engine, and AWS's virtualization.
Have you ever used C or C++? I can see how this thinking would make sense from the outside but it just doesn't track from the inside.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91253786
The people working on fish right now don't like C++ and CMake despite being experienced users. Refactoring can't solve the fundamental problem there.
Rust's thread safety is way way better than C++'s, so refactoring can't solve that either. (That's the "concurrent function execution" thing.)
I don't know if it will lead to more contributors overall, but there's a good chance this will turn me into a contributor. I've contributed to fish in the past but only to the shell code, not to the C++ core, because I don't know C++. I do know Rust.
>wouldn't they be better served by starting fresh with a new project unencumbered by 2 decades of baggage?
If it doesn't do the nice things fish does for me I'm not using it, and if I'm not using it I'm not going to contribute to it.
A 1:1 module-by-module port is probably a quicker route to get there than starting from the ground up.

Do you have visual-line-mode enabled globally perhaps? If yes you can solve this by enabling it only in buffers you want it. Usually this would only be in text buffers, some people use it in prog buffers too.
A lot of people seem to say that you should use icomplete-vertical-mode instead since fido is for ido historical compatibility only. I expect you would probably have the same issue with that if the problem is that visual-line-mode is enabled globally.
You can see it's state with `C-h v visual-line-mode` if it's nil that's not the problem. If it's true then try toggling it with M-x visual-line-mode.

posts.com:
There are well-known trade offs when switching from dynamic to static typing and vice versa. The usual issues with dynamic range from performance to type checking.

I heard someone (Paul Graham) say that none of this applies to Lisp, because it is dynamic by design and it wouldn't gain anything by having types. How does Lisp reconcile static-dynamic typing and solve all the problems with a single design?

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91247560
Lisp is too high level for this kind of considerations so it solves these problems by not giving a fuck about them.
The foundational data structure of lisp is a linked list, we don't really give a fuck about performance here but care about things like expressiveness and homoiconicity.
I shouldn't give you the impression that lisps are all slow shits though I wouldn't except even toy lisp implementations to perform worse than python, but it's not a systems programming language designed to be optimized out of the ass.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91247560
Everything is dynamic until you get down to the compiler level, and then you can write static code if you want more performance. This static code is more verbose and awkward to read/write but matches or beats C in performance while maintaining complete compatibility with normal dynamic code. Obviously there's a performance loss if you cross the boundary too often, so usually static code is isolated loops called into by dynamic code.
The bets part is since even this static code exists in a dynamic framework, you can interactively alter or redefine any of it whenever you want. At least most of it, there is a core down at a certain level which is always static and can't be changed, but usually there's no reason to mess with it.

tl:dr - there's a small core of statically compiled lisp that can be thought of as inline assembly, and with proper tags you can have dynamic lisp code compile into this form for increase performance without losing your ability to use toplevel dynamic code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91247885
Types only exist in tightly optimized code where everything is explicitly typed, everywhere else you just get exceptions thrown if you try to do something that doesn't work. Generics/Methods can get kinda slow, but that's about it.
Basically 100% of the time types don't exist in lisp aside from the obvious list/function/variable distinction, and in scheme you don't even have function/variable distinction! I mean it still won't work if you try to run a numeric literal as a function, but it'll make the attempt before throwing an exception.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91245767
Ask Emacs first.
C-h v org-html-postamble

org-html-postamble is a variable defined in ‘ox-html.el’.

Its value is ‘auto’

Non-nil means insert a postamble in HTML export.

When set to ‘auto’, check against the
‘org-export-with-author/email/creator/date’ variables to set the
content of the postamble. When t, insert a string as defined by the
formatting string in ‘org-html-postamble-format’. When set to a
string, use this formatting string instead (see
‘org-html-postamble-format’ for an example of such a formatting
string).

When set to a function, apply this function and insert the
returned string. The function takes the property list of export
options as its only argument.

Setting :html-postamble in publishing projects will take
precedence over this variable.

posts.com: is the only meaningful difference between a lisp 1 and lisp 2 that functions have their own namespace? every once in a while I see someone bitching about 1 or 2 and it seems, at best trivial, that you can't name your list "list" because it's already reserved...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91260119
lisp-1s seem more "elegant" because you only need a single assignment operator for everything and can therefore more easily do shit with let/lambda and don't need gensym/flet/labels/defun/etc...
Personally I agree, the only argument I've ever heard for 2s are performance, which I can't see being legitimate in most instances since you already can't redefine certain symbols, and shit with macros/dynamic evaluation, which I see as at worst equivalently awkward as gensym/flet/etc and often much simpler.

In the end it's just because CL is a 2 and scheme is a 1, and aside from 1v2 CL and Scheme ARE actually significantly different so it becomes tribalism.
Personally I like CL AND 1, which is just awkward for me.
The only objective superiority of 2 is you can implement 1 with a type checking macro, but 2 ontop of 1 is effectively impossible. But you don't see me coding everything inside a macro so that doesn't really matter.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91256880
>what LSP do you use?
I think I use pyright now because it came out of the box.
DAP is the debugger and it's great. With DAP you can get an amazingly interactive development experience.
I start my debugger as I develop python, and I evaluate code on the fly with my hacked together send-to-repl function.
I've posted this snippet here before and it's almost getting embarrassing, but I just never want to code Python without it or something similar again.

  (defun my/dap-dwim-eval-repl ()
    "Evaluate code in the dap-debug repl.
If a region is active, evaluate the active region.
Otherwise evaluate the current line."
    (interactive)
    (if (use-region-p)
        (insert-into-buffer
         (get-buffer "*dap-ui-repl*") (mark) (point))
      (insert-into-buffer (get-buffer "*dap-ui-repl*")
                          (line-beginning-position)
                          (line-end-position)))
    (with-current-buffer "*dap-ui-repl*"
      (comint-send-input))))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91247807
>Do you build patches from scratch each time, or have you saved "starter" templates with routing in place for different kinds of patches?
Both, but since it is semi-modular you have to use templates for the things that you do constantly, especially for Multipass and Snap Heap, and making heavy use of the macro knobs is a must. When you start using Phase Plant it is better to just make patches normally, but you make sure to use the macro knobs, preset description, and you don't leave things messy, so by doing this all of your patches are going to become "templates", and over time you will be able to just jump in and load previous patches as templates instead of starting from scratch. Also the same thing for Multipass and Snap Heap, but instead of template for sounds it will be templates for effects, so with Multipass it would be things like OTT, and with Snap Heap for things like a specific reverb that you've built. So in the end Phase Plant can be quicker and way more complex than Pigments, but it takes some dedication to reach that point.

>so I’m not sure to see what Phase Plant would bring me
Autist here: the pros of Phase Plant boil down to mostly flexibility of modulation and its bundled effects/enviroment, as the other anon already explained about multi-pass and snapheap.
Contrary to what i've seen most people seen, the oscillator section with its audiorate modulation, while flexible, isn't actually *that* useful ime outside of creating niche FX, or making sounds similar to what you can do elsewhere (so just the flexibility, again).

The single reason I downloaded Phase Plant is that, for whatever technical reason, it imports wavetables at the initial stage far better than Serum, (any synth that I know of, supposedly, but that may not be true), and there are a few effect that can be applied, of course.
That alone makes it worth having for me, but obviously that's a niche need.

Sidenote that probably doesn't matter to anybody: I still retain that phase plant shouldn't be grouped in with the likes of vital, serum, pigments etc. All of those tend to excel at the same types of sounds and have a very similar flow to them that phase plant does not share.... my notes don't cover that for some reason

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91252380
>Bbsus#4
what

1, 3, and 6 all share two notes so they're closely related and don't feel like you're moving much and can give a sort of melancholy sound. chords that move by minor thirds sound/feel this way. sus is sometimes used to give motion to a chord so it doesn't sound boring, like instead of playing C for 4 beats you can play C for 2 beats and Csus4 for the other two beats which is how i see it used in that song. the Dm Fsus4 is similar to the first concept: Dm is DFA so the Fsus is to make it still sound like you're still on Dm instead of sounding like you've moved to Fmajor. the chord motion by minor third is probably the most applicable thing, Bb is the minor third of Gm, C is the m3 of A and so on

I use a 57 through a scarlett solo and for vocals, it leans quite dark and lacks presence... a lot of people use them still obviously and they're not *wrong,* but obviously if you want a modern, polished sound, they may not be the best for a home setup (inb4 "but pros..." - they're using high end preamps and it's not a fair comparison).

Some people bring up that cheaper condensers have a characteristic harshness to the high end (arguably negating the benefits compared to my complaint about a 57), but that's up for debate- i've only tested one, some blue mic, an ember I believe, and I didn't hear that at all, though of course itt was much brighter, louder, and picked up more room noise.

>as a beginner
I don't think it's that big of an issue skill wise, but it's harder to fuck up the actual sound of the recording with a dynamic.

As for assessing your room, the actual answer is to hire an acoustician.Tools like room EQ Wizard exist but afaik that's just for analyzing the response in your room.

just to clarify, it can be major or minor thirds. since chords are constructed by stacking thirds on top of each other, chords a 3rd up or down are more like a prolongation of the original chord. this is a much softer motion than if you moved 2nds or by 4ths/5ths.

https://youtu.be/6R8EdPvX0ZY?t=348
this 2 minute clip is part of a good video on harmony that keiichi okabe uses in nier songs. he mixes a lot of jazz and classical concepts to write atmospheric, gloomy songs. when you analyze songs, look at how chords function in the key but also if the chords are tertian intervals of the chords near them

>>91263272
I use it but it's a weird distro to recommend to others. For example, it has two update commands and you should never use the other one (zypper up will break tumbleweed, use zypper dup instead). Repos are split if you want to have codecs and are not always on sync. The package manager has no parallel downloads. You have to set up zypper repo priorities manually to get smooth running updates(1st packman, 2nd official repos, 3rd OBS, etc), I dunno if this is better or worse than Fedora where it just chooses the newest package and not caring about repo priorities. Despite the quirks I like it because there are exclusive features out of the box.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91266119
I just spent several days trying to get videos to work on firefox so here are some tips to save you the trouble. The most important thing to do is to install the ffmpeg-5 package, for whatever reason ffmpeg-4 is installed by default and that won't work. Then install the packages provided by the repo desctibed here https://news.opensuse.org/2023/01/24/opensuse-simplifies-codec-install/ , the repo should be enabled by default if you use the latest installation media so you don't have to add it again. The particular packages you want are gstreamer-1.20-plugin-openh264, libopenh264-7 and mozilla-openh264. That's all you need, no need to mess with Packman repos unless you need specific codecs or hardware acceleration for your system.

posts.com:
>>91232553
If your phone number is public record this is a possibility, if you're using 2fa through sms it should be on a number that's never been published online for anything and as others have mentioned it's ultimately just a stopgap. In the case of an email address having a really good and not bruteforceable (within reason) or dictionary attack vulnerable pw will help, change it minimum every 3-6 months, never save it on anything electronic, and then also require 2fa after password AND email notifications of login attempts sent to preferably a different address you also control. Ultimately some sort of physical security key is the best solution but at that point your threat model is being a journalist reporting sensitive material trying to not get your head cut off for it. For the average person doing what I've mentioned, not clicking every link under the sun (ip grabbers) and just generally not talking mad shit about another country where there's any identifiable information about yourself present or preferably not doing it at all is going to keep you safe. As others have mentioned they probably got pwned via malware on their personal machine or phone as that would be the easiest attack vector.

In general, don't join cyberwars. You will become a target eventually and you will fuck up eventually.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91258105
Nothing will happen.
If you want something to happen, you can use undefined behavior sanitizer on clang (won't work on GCC) and enable -fsanitize=implicit-conversion, which is an extension of -fsanitizer=undefined (there are other ubsan flags you can also enable for clang, but this is the one for narrowing, and if you used signed integers, that would trigger ubsan by default).
if you use -Wnarrow, you could remove the warning by using something like:
int main() {
    std::istringstream iss("257");
    int test;
    if(iss >> test)
    {
#pragma GCC diagnostic push
#pragma GCC diagnostic ignored "-Wnarrow"
    unsigned char cast = test;
#pragma GCC diagnostic pop
        printf("%d", cast);
    }
}

You could also write a macro for this to work using _Pragma.
I use clang-tidy, and it takes a lot of work to find which settings you want and which settings you don't want, but the narrowing check is included in the bugprone-* subcategory, and to remove the warning you can just do:
// NOLINTNEXTLINE(bugprone-narrowing-conversions)
.
If you use static_cast you will cancel the check for -fsanitize=implicit-conversion
https://godbolt.org/z/v5Pdz4MYq

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91260540
just decouple the QT and core logic if you don't want QT to kidnap your program.
the idea is that if you stop using QT, you can easily switch frameworks because you have a generic interface that uses very basic API that all UI's would support.
This wouldn't work with a complex UI or if you valued performance over everything, but every GUI library will kidnap your code at that point.
Also there are good arguments to say that if your code only needs to run on windows, you should just use C# and use WinUI or whatever fits your goals better.
You could even make C++ your backend, and use C# as the frontend.

>>91262309
Generally, struct packing rules for most compilers are described here pretty thoroughly: http://www.catb.org/esr/structure-packing/
But the standard only guarantees there is no padding before the first element, no other guarantees are made about consecutive types, etc., so you shouldn't assume it will work.
In practice people still use stuff like:
union vec3 {
    struct {
        float x, y, z;
    };
    float elements[3];
};

because it works with their compiler. If you want to know whether it will work or not for any given compiler you can do something like this
static_assert(offsetof(struct vec3, x) == offsetof(struct vec3, elements[0], "Bad layout for x");
static_assert(offsetof(struct vec3, y) == offsetof(struct vec3, elements[1], "Bad layout for y");
static_assert(offsetof(struct vec3, z) == offsetof(struct vec3, elements[2], "Bad layout for z");

to check the layout at compile time, and you can force particular padding using compiler specific attributes:
(see aligned and packed)
https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Common-Type-Attributes.html#Common-Type-Attributes
or pragmas
https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Structure-Layout-Pragmas.html#Structure-Layout-Pragmas

>>91265486
This shows a 6x8 grid, with first picture taking 3x2 space. Such layouts are easy to generate.
It's clearly row based, so it's several 6x2 on top of eachother. Basically canvas_width / 6, divided into sections for the pictures, if 1x1 another added below it. The images are then resized by height and placed inside, plus cropped if needed.

>>91265602
This one is dynamic height for columns. Easiest way is probably doing 0 to 20, 20 to 45, 45 to 60 and so on randomly with minimum and maximum values. To avoid gap, assign leftover height to the others.

If you have images of varying aspect ratios, you can take their height or width, iterate over lists of them, and store all results that fit canvas. It's really the aspect ratio difference your after, so 200x200 is equal to 100x100, 500x300 is 166~/100. Basically width / (height / 100).

Probably dozens of other ways to do it. But you only need gradeschool math and the very basics of programming for this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91214534
I covered some basic cases and tricks already but to summarize, signatures have a lot of weight put on them, your honor and word. People like to abuse that if you let them. What won't save your job will rape your former employer in court. What you need varies by problem presented. Some of this is specific to clerical work and will get funny looks and derision if it's not a core part of your job, until you're in court. Then documents talk.

>Distinct, photocopy evident ink
>Feeling for pen impressions on the back of signatures
>Custom stamps
>Absolute consistency in what you use and where you use it.
>Locking your shit up behind a medeco or abloy lock (good employers don't question why you need an expensive and obscure high security lock, bad employers are rife with fraud and embezzlement)
>Dating signatures
>Overlapping dates with signatures and stamps
>Changing signatures every few months
>Consistent signatures
All this is bank teller or state agency stuff. DMV tier. They also have a lot of serialized paper for official docs and checks but even mundane paperwork is carefully stamped and signed.

Less secure environments with less trust and little oversight need other solutions. Usually clandestine methods. Mechanics leave greasy fingerprints on their initials, easy to lift and forge but surprisingly effective. I mark initials with my thumbnail in a specific pattern. The aforementioned rotating stable of signatures also applies. Not really secure or the best for authentication but it makes you immediately aware when something is not yours. These tend to be more for seeing who's been sleeping in your bed when you aren't around. It's like putting tape on a door to see if it's been opened.

That's all I've got off the top of my head before you get into systems of policy compliance and stuff that overlaps with forensic accounting.

>be adult

Dude, what is wrong with you, you are missing a fantastic world.
There are tons of reason to change your habit
>Haptic pleasure
>Quality of writing
>Tons of ink
>Tons of nibs
>Potentially more economical on the long run than cheap pen if you want
>Less damaging for the environment
Guys, come on, you can get an awesome starting pen for 10-15 dollars/euro!
Below the best entry level (their quality of writing is not that inferior to more expensive pens).
In best starting options
> Platinum Preppy
Very cheap, depends on where you live, but you can get it with 5–8 bucks. It writes well, but you feel like It will break in your hands.
Platinum Prefounte costs 10 bucks, it's the upgrade of Preppy, same pen but much more solid.
> Pilot Kakuno
Amazing entry level pen, its only flaw is the childish design.
It's Japanese, and Japanese fine nibs draw thinner lines than their European counterpart.
Pilot Metropolitan is its upgrade, much cooler design and it's metallic.
> Lamy Safari
THE student pen. Lamy did a good job promoting it, it is maybe the most sold fountain pen worldwide and for a reason. It is solid, you can see if it is out of ink, it is really easy to change nib and as a triangular grip.
This last feature helps you to learn how to hold the pen, but it limits you and can be uncomfortable if you have big hands like me or if you like to change your grip.
Al Star is its upgrade made in alluminium. I suggest you to stick with Safari if it is your first pen.
> Diplomat Magnum
It remembers a lot Lamy Safari, same price, but actually... Better quality. Very similar design and feature, has a converter and surprisingly good nibs. If I'll have to buy a Safari today, I'll take this one instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
> Kaweco Perkeo
Kaweco brand is amazing. Cheap portable pen but all the money you spend are 100% quality. Why are they so cheap?
Easy: no metallic clip.
Perkeo is a solid starting pen, it cost like 10-15 buck. The star of Kaweco is Kaweco sport, 20 buck, it feels like a cigar pen when you write, robust, reliable, enter your pockets, great, just great.

Honorable mentions
> Pelikan twist
Pen made for Kids, nice design, robust, medium nib and triangular section. A pen made for Battle.
> Jinhao
Chinese brand for the most chinese product you may get. They copy designs of other brands and have some of their own, I never write with one of their pen but they are cheap and their customers are usually happy with the quality. You may give a shot.
>TWSBI
Great brand, sadly I do not suggest their cheapest models. They started with one demostrator, Diamond, 70 buck. The cheaper pens do not feel like an introduction to the brand but as downgrades. TWSBI Eco, 40 bucks, is very good, but the others are... Well, nor satisfying nor for newbies actually. They are more for same brand user that wants something cheaper to throw in a bag.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91246954
Get the bullet journal book off libgen and make an all in one day planner and diary. It scales really nice to any need and the indexing and how you move tasks forward makes it a very powerful tool for identifying patterns. I'd skip the back half of the book as it's mostly self help but it has some neat methods for project management. It helped me eat better and save money. I also realized one of my friends wasn't a good influence during a year end review, little things and big patterns emerged.

Deep into the self help side, you get a snapshot of your mental state which is a good thing to have if it goes wrong. Melancholy and mania are reflected in your handwriting and use of language and given enough entries over time, you stop falling for your own bullshit. I try to stay out of this side of journaling when I talk about it, but I've seen some spectacular results with minor issues. They disappear under observation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91253280
I'd go for a fineliner like a Micron, Uni Pin, or Staedtler fineliner. For a Micron it would be in a fat tip like 08, 10, or 12. It's guaranteed not to leak.
From personal experience here is the leakiness order best to worst:
fineliners > ballpoints > gel pens > rollerballs (liquid ink) > fountain pens.

However I find it unusual that "cheap pens" you have leak, since cheap pens are usually standard ballpoints which rarely leak at all. Just how much vibration are you subjecting those poor pens to?
Are you leavin them on a tray in the train?

My second choice would be something like a Uniball Jetstream ballpoint.
If you're leavin them on a hard surface you could wrap them in braided paracord to dampen vibrations (search for how online) or make a little foam pen tray, that way you can use any pen you want without fear of leakage.

Not very, unless IRL steganographic whoms't'veposting tickles yr fancy. I learned it from my grandmother and filled in my skills a few years back just for the fuck of it. If you're reasonably intelligent, it should only take someone an afternoon to learn the basics and a few weeks to get a feel for the abbreviations and make some of your own. Earlier editions are designed specifically for turn of the century court reporting and meeting minutes while later editions are simplified for dictation and a bit slower but easier to learn.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91264648
When I was learning cursive I was writing my letters double size, that may help
Otherwise honestly it's just practice, you've got years and years of muscle memory from writing with your wrist and fingers, so you probably wouldn't expect your arm/shoulder to be as dextrous right off the bat
With time and conscious effort you can learn to write with larger muscle groups, but there really is no need to go full autist over it, back in the day, back when scribe was an actual job, people needed to use the larger muscle groups like the shoulder because they tire much slower, and the tools and handwriting style of the day were made to fit that style, somewhat
Today you'll hardly be writing for long periods, the reason why I learned to write with my shoulder was because my fingers and hand would cramp up really badly when I was sitting exams, but now my exams are all computer based, even the fucking maths ones, the longest periods that I ever write for are while studying
So I'm mostly somewhere in the middle, no fingers, some wrist, a bit of arm, and some shoulder

Yes, and the process of unloading and reloading is called... yes! restarting!

>>91263070
Looks pretty straightforward I made a shitty 3D game with some wack engine that would run on first iPad
It was easier than I thought, you just had entities which you added to the engine which were essentially visible models and you set properties on each that had physics vectors
you had a base class of the entity and your derived custom classes had these properties
each derived type could of course be manipulated at runtime since there was a collection of all entities
On events from say collisions or inputs could modify these entities

So you could add a type of entity that’s a sphere, set them on a collision course and when they collide you further modify the world or just let em bounce off
Every object can have gravity shit like that

That’s my understanding of how these game engines all work and if it’s not strictly object oriented the architecture just models that idea

posts.com:
>>91244117
>what is today[ESL sic]
Yeah, what it is today. Which is a general-purpose game engine that can make most types of game and does a lot of things that third-party libraries would do if you're making your own engine. Your own engine is not a general-purpose game engine, it's likely for one game / series / style of game that you make. And that means the requirements are drastically lower than for a general-purpose engine.

Brainlets assume making your own engine means making an equivalent to Unreal or Unity, when it really doesn't. You don't need to be able to support a bazillion different gameplay paradigms, you don't need to be able to support a ton of different graphic styles, etc. You just need one. And a lot of the things that an engine does for you are things that you just grab a library for when making your own, like serialization, UI, thread pool (also Unreal/Unity's thread pooling are utter dogshit compared to BS::thread_pool), etc.

The workload for making a dedicated in-house engine for a specific game is nowhere near the workload for making a general-purpose commercial game engine targeted at third party developers.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91244203
That's because Vulkan gives you full control over what you do with a GPU. You have to specify that stuff, that's what full control means. Having the API do it for you would defeat the purpose, especially since Vulkan isn't a graphics API, it's a GPU API, and can't make assumptions about what you're going to do with a GPU. Maybe you're just going to do compute tasks with it in a console program and never present anything directly to the monitor.

If you want to leave shit up to the API then use OpenGL. The performance difference between AZDO OpenGL and Vulkan isn't going to be much different.

Making a game engine to trudge thru and learn the concepts of making angines is a great idea, otherwise it depends on the scope of what you wanna do. Pre-made engines have the more advanced stuff already figured out (for example, porting to other platforms the engine supports is piss easy).

At the same time, for simpler games you don't need an engine whatsoever - you can absolutely bang out a 2D game using SDL or w/e in a feasible amount of time.

Basically - check what technologies your game needs. If there's a lot of them or if you want some space-tech level shit then go with a pre-existing engine, but feel free to futz about with a self-made engine implementation of these things on the side, to get a feel for how they work on a lower lever.
Otherwise feel free to skip an entire engine and just stick to basic libraries of windowing, graphics, sound etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91244099
Because making a game and making an engine are two largely different tasks, and most people who try to create their own engine in order to create a game end up with a half-baked engine and no game. Unity literally started out as an effort to make an engine for a game; 17 years later and the authors created an industry-standard engine, but still didn't make their own game.

If you're a programmer who wants to fuck around and learn, then trying to make your own engine is good exercise. But if your goal is to actually create a game, then starting out by building an engine is kinda like going about baking bread by constructing an oven first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91244099
Most hobbyist and indie devs just want to make a game. Making an engine, even for a simple 2d game, you quickly lose sight of what you set out to build. Before you know it you're building all kinds of tools and designing file formats and all kinds of things like that instead of just working on your game. Using an existing engine gives you a lot out of the box.

The happy medium I think is just pick an open source engine with a permissive licence that'll let you fork it. And should you need to do some customisation for rendering or whatever, you can just modify it or pick one which lets you customise things without having to change the main source (some kind of module/plugin driven architecture, again something you don't need to waste time building yourself).

In the old days, smaller indie studios could get away with their own engine because it was: heavily optimised based on the kind of games they made and they could re-use for multiple games. And in a time when people actually bought licensed proprietary software, they also had a commercial angle to license the engine to other studios. Today given the wide variety of engines that cover a lot of the common use cases (and a lot with the source available or some SaaS model).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Neither Unreal Engine nor Unity support floating point determinism. So if you want to use floating point numbers and also have deterministic lockstep multiplayer (a staple of the strategy genre, where transmitting the entire game state would be impractical), you can't use either engine. Not "you shouldn't use either engine", you literally can't.

Floating point determinism isn't hard to achieve in C++. But with the bloatmaxxed shitheaps that are Unreal and Unity, designed as they are for shooters and other such goyslop where the whole gamestate is transmitted, rollback is employed where necessary, and it doesn't matter if each user's simulation is a bit off, you CANNOT get floating point determinism.

If you want to make a strategy game with multiplayer then you're basically going to be stuck writing your own netcode if you want it to work. Unity strategy games, such as everything Amplitude makes, are plagued with desync issues because the bloated niggerlicious engine doesn't have floating point determinism and player simulations routinely diverge. Sweeney has straight up declared (wrongly) that you can't have cross-platform floating point determinism in software (we know this isn't true because RTS devs have been doing it in their in-house engines for decades) and that it doesn't matter anyways, so you won't get any better results in Unreal. At best you'll have to implement some bloated niggerlicious rollback-based network choking system like the Stormgate devs are doing with UE5.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91262816
you don't need determinism if you accept that floats are inaccurate and just have the server adjust for the error that accumulates.

https://gafferongames.com/post/floating_point_determinism/

Modern engines have abandoned the idea of getting exact float reproductions out because there is too much variation in hardware. Even if you do everything perfectly in software if someone's CPU does some weird shit that introduces error you're fucked

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: >>91246054

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91263464
You can't read. You haven't even read the article you linked.
>deterministic lockstep multiplayer
There is no server. RTS game states have way too much data. You just send player inputs from each player to every other player. They all simulate exactly the same and send a checksum, and if there is any deviation the game is deemed out of sync.

IEEE 754-compliant floats ARE deterministic across hardware. As long as you don't turn on compiler settings that allow them to abandon compliance and you do not do more than one floating point operation per statement, you will get deterministic simulations across different platforms. RTS developers have been doing this for decades. It is proven to work. Unity and Unreal can't do it.

posts.com:
For the anon interested in learning business from previous thread:

"Business" at a company level is supply & demand. Business balances external need (customer demand) with internal capability to meet that need (supply).

But there's also "business" at a macro level, because customer demands and your ability to produce are rarely isolated from the broader economy. So that's understanding aggregate demand with aggregate supply and how they impact customers and your productivity. (Balancing this is the Fed's task)

For a first step, you should really understand who is using your product and why. That's basically the entire job of Product "Owners" and Product Managers. Learn why people are paying for your product, and why some of them leave and churn. Go one step further and figure out what is a need that is not met, then build your own startup to fill that gap.

>>91255597
Look it up. Better yet, try it out. It works surprisingly often.
When you face an issue you find difficult to resolve, a change of perspective might be all you need. That's why asking a colleague and explaining the issue to them is often enough for you to find the solution even without them answering or even understanding the issue in the first place.
Hence, rubber duck debugging. You get an inanimate object (a rubber duck, for example) and tell it about what should be happening, how you're hoping to achieve it and what's going wrong. Since the rubber duck is a fucking duck made of rubber, it doesn't know shit about coding.
You'll have to take on a teacher's perspective and explain every little tiny detail. There you go. You're forced to go through every little step with a different perspective. Sounds insane, but it works. Not as useful as talking to an actual colleague, obviously, but handy in case nobody's available.
Personally, I talk to a chinkshit Dragonair plushie when working from home. It's too big to take to the office though, that's why I'm asking around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91222305
I've recently bought some bluedio t7 and I'm really really liking them. I upgraded from bluedio t4 and while the t4 was only just over the ear, the ear cups are easily over the ear on these. They're not that deep though, so if you've got sticky outy ears, they might be uncomfortable. The sound is good, I'm not an audiophile, but it's plenty good and pretty fast, I've used them at home for gaming and it was totally fine, I didn't notice any major lag.
One really really nice thing is the build quality is great. The band is metal and feels rock solid and the auto-play-pause when you put the headset on or take it off works great in my experience.
They're also quite quiet, which is a bonus for me, because I listen to everything pretty quiet in comparison to people. Also the ANC is straight trash. It can remove some deeper stuff or consistent noise if you're on a plane, but it drops a lot of bass and adds a kind of hiss.

Overall, I like em, given their price. They sound good, they feel solid, battery lasts well and they're comfortable enough to last me through a work day without being uncomfortable

>>91228757
All phone software is designed to cope with latency.
When you play a video, it will sync up the audio with the video seamlessly.
If you are gaming on your phone, get a USB-C to 3.5 mm adapter and use the wire, because everything wireless will have some delay.
If you use a PC, there are no protocols, you only have lag, unless you really want to buy an expensive adapter.
Personally if you use your phone a lot, your requirement should be "does this headphone multi-pair?", and the answer is probably not, unless you buy something super expensive like a sony XM4 (note, they go on a 60% sale frequently, but they are still very expensive).

>>91244721
one of the annoying things about mixers is that a lot of mixers have a problem with latency, and it has nothing to do with the mixing itself (its should be analog), but it has everything to do with the analog to digital converter (which is inside a mixer that has a USB interface).
so if you were a streamer with a facecam, you would actually need to delay your camera by a couple frames so that your audio is synced to the video (depending on how much latency the camera has as well).
and this can even apply to $200 mixers.

>>91260287
just plug the 3.5mm jack of your casset player into the microphone jack of your PC (some new pc's have a TRRS 3.5mm instead of TRS which means the same port is used for headphones and microphones headsets, and only output speaker TRS plugs are backwards compatible).
The audio might not be perfect, since your PC might have a bad analog to digital converter (might not be the fault of the chip, it might just be a ton of electrical noise from the other components or something in your room).
If you want better quality, you could buy a mixer like this anon (but you would need to buy a 3.5mm to XLR adpater, and because this mixer doesn't have a usb interface, you need another $20 on a USB analog to digital converter, for example a behringer ucontrol which can be relatively expensive):
>>91244721

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91261746

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91261746
Wait, bad idea, the signal levels are way off and it can damage the computer.
I thought the line-in plug was the same as the microphone plug, but that line-in has the correct level for some 3.5mm output from a cassette player.
Also you could actually you can use a 3.5mm to 6.35mm adapter instead of the XLR adapter (and it's much cheaper), The mixer's XLR plug is a 2-in-1 that supports the 6.35mm TRS plug (only downside is that it doesn't support XLR's balance wire).
Also I haven't done this personally, it might be possible that the input from the cassette player might have a signal that's too strong, but I think the HI-Z button should fix that (but some mixers don't have that button).

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

>Portable programs & partitioning for reinstall-proofing
https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

>I miss Windows##

No.

>>91263437
>But AppData is inside your user folder.
And it's the only folder than can't be moved since it doesn't have a "Location" tab in its properties. Even the OP says as much.
>Moving user folders to second partition or 2nd drive:
>Go into C:\Users\username.
>Right click on a folder you want to relocate and select Properties.
>Go to the Location tab, and enter in a new location for the folder (example: C:\Users\username\My Documents -> D:\My Documents)
>Do this for every folder with a Location tab.
>Now when an application or game saves user files, it should save to your second partition/drive instead of C:\Users\username, unless the dev is one of those drooling retards that saves data to AppData, there's nothing you can do about them.

posts.com:
>>91264590
It was relevant before most of /g/ was born. There were a number of things that contributed to "Windows rot" in XP and earlier, like:
>keeping the registry in its entirety
Even during inplace upgrades, which were steadily corrupting and bloating the hive files, and they were never consistency checked or repacked. This all changed in Vista: now there's a cut-down version of USMT built into Windows Setup, so you get a pristine SOFTWARE and SYSTEM hive every "upgrade", and Vista also introduced transactional registry functions - so if you've ever wondered why registry corruptions/failures are so rare since Vista, now you know.
>everyone was a fucking administrator
Which opened all sorts of lovely doors for trashing not just HKCU, but HKLM, writing random files all over C: drive, and generally causing unmitigated disaster.
All of these problems are solved, and as such, people who experience "Windows rot" in 2023 are invariably Dunning-Kruger retards who've disabled UAC, made themselves administrators, and run memescripts that make it easier to corrupt the registry. I have no doubt >>91264606 falls into this category - as he demonstrates in >>91264618, he really has no awareness of what he's doing. Just "using it" doesn't trash your Windows install - trashing your Windows install trashes your Windows install.

>>91253619
>1. Train AI to create better AI
easily said, not so easily done. the way that things like stable diffusion and chatgpt are trained is by giving them fuck-huge datasets (tagged images and text, respectively) so what you'd have to do is give an AI examples of other AI models and what they're good at, in some quantifiable way. You'd be making a meta-AI, essentially, and that's a nontrivial problem that'd require very nontrivial computation. Is it prohibited by the laws of physics, no, but will we see it in the next few decades? I doubt it.

My guess is that this'll be a replay, on a grander scale, of what you saw in the 80s and 90s with "expert systems". We'll figure out how to make AIs improve themselves within a specific domain. Like, as mentioned above, generating images or text, given a prompt. But sentience? A "will of its own"? No. We have no idea how to do that. Modern AI is basically pattern-matching writ large. We didn't create minds, we created a system that can run a metric fuckton of computation to solve the problem of "find an [image, text] that is statistically similar to [images, text] described by these terms." It isn't going to decide on its own that the whole world needs to be paperclips.

Would we know that what we create has qualia? No, but we would know if it is generally intelligent.

>>91255520
>How do you think intelligence works?
I don't think there is any specific way intelligence works. Intelligence is a result, not a method. There are likely many different methods that can result in intelligence.
Our brains, which happens to have qualia (for reasons we have literally no idea about), is intelligent, but a sample size of one is obviously not even close to enough to draw any conclusions that any intelligent system therefore also has qualia.
>What do you suppose qualia has to do with the comprehension of abstract patterns?
Literally no one knows what qualia is and why it exists, so this is still pointless to speculate about. But again I don't think it's necessarily very relevant.
>No intelligent being can think in Boolean.
Again, we have a sample size of one for intelligent beings. That is not enough to make statements about what intelligent beings can and can't do. But we can actually reason that yes, intelligent beings CAN think in boolean. Read up on the Orthogonality Thesis. There is no reason to think there is any correlation of complexity of goal (even down to a single boolean state), and intelligence.
>Even for a pragmatic and thoroughly materialist outlook on the problem, you have exactly zero proof of the intelligent design of consciousness being brute-forced. Not just in human beings
Am I misunderstanding you or are you denying evolution or invoking supernaturality/religion? If so I have no interest in the direction this discussion is heading.
>If we were nothing but a bundle of neurons, ions and engraved information then our AI would have long since become self-aware
Not really, because they are not build with the tools to be self-aware, such as sensors telling them about the world and their place in it. All they have is static data. If we instead emulated a human perfectly with electronics, then yes, I do believe it WOULD be self-aware. This is likely unprovable but I believe consciousness is but a byproduct of system behaviors.

posts.com:
>>91251347
>But unless we crack quantum consciousness (improbable) and Moore's law doesn't die/we make gigantic leaps in quantum computing (impossible) then you're looking at close to 0% chance.
Quantum stuff isn't really in the picture. It might be part of how the brain does things with so little energy, but it isn't doing computation; the environment is too noisy with all those water molecules about.
Instead, you need to think more in terms of having large numbers of simple compute elements that talk to each other. Short term memories and thinking are largely in ad hoc networks, and longer term things are done by rewiring the connections. The brain does very little creation of new neurons, but it does change the synapses that connect them a lot. What the minimum model of computation within a neuron is is a total open question (and not one the current simulator generation is quite able to tackle).
I guess there's a sense in which your brain actually does its computation with time and patterns. It's not at all like any ordinary computer. But that doesn't mean we can't build things like that. It's not impossible at all, it's just very different and there are decades of bad assumptions to undo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91254025
>Is it prohibited by the laws of physics, no, but will we see it in the next few decades? I doubt it.
I'm more optimistic than you, but I don't think the current normal machine learning approach will work. The back-propagation-through-time approach is just far too inefficient and resource hungry. It's not quite at the point where Google and Microsoft have to call time on the approach, but only big corps can really afford the main part of big AI training right now and that's a red flag for future viability of the approach. There's gotta be a better way.
I believe that neuromorphic computing might be that better way. Signs are promising, especially when they're not going purely rate coded. (In nature, only motor neurons are rate coded, and that's because they're driving muscles that have to effectively integrate their inputs.)
