You can create a RISC architecture. But it will be slow as shit. We have pretty much reached the limit of how fast individual instructions can be executed, the only way to make a cpu fast is to many specialized instructions to accelerate common operations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91266524
So wasn't CISC superior when the CISC-RISC was was a thing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91266725
so, way back in the 80s, this was a big debate. to oversimplify a bit, the advantage of CISC was instruction density. The bigger your instruction set, the more things you can have instructions for, obviously, so code that accomplishes some given task takes fewer instructions - it's smaller, which saves both memory and bus bandwidth. The advantage of RISC was that it permitted a simpler implementation inside the CPU. Instruction decoding was a bottleneck that took a bunch of die area, if you could streamline it you could make a CPU that ran faster. So what was the better tradeoff to make? As always, "it depends".

This distinction grew far less important over time. CISCs became RISCy, at least internally, and RISCs became CISCier.

> me:
#define _XOPEN_SOURCE 500

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

#define DECK_SIZE 52
#define SET_SEED() do { void *addr = malloc(0); srandom((long)addr); free(addr); } while(0)

typedef enum suit {
    HEARTS = 0,
    DIAMONDS,
    SPADES,
    CLUBS,
} suit;

static const char *suit_name[] = { "HEARTS", "DIAMONDS", "SPADES", "CLUBS" };

typedef struct card {
    short rank;
    suit suit;
} card;

void shuffle(card *cards, size_t cards_size, size_t shuffles) {
    size_t max_retry = 60;

    for(size_t idx = 0; idx < shuffles; idx++) {
        size_t a = random() % cards_size;
        size_t b = 0;
        size_t try = 0;
        while((b = random() % cards_size) == a && try++ < max_retry) ;

        card tmp = cards[a];
        cards[a] = cards[b];
        cards[b] = tmp;
    }
}

int main(void) {
    SET_SEED();
    card cards[DECK_SIZE];

    for(short s = 0; s < 4; s++) {
        for(short r = 1; r <= 13; r++) {
            short idx = r - 1 + s * 13;
            cards[idx] = (card){r, s};
        }
    }

    shuffle(cards, DECK_SIZE, DECK_SIZE);

    printf("Chosen cards: ");
    size_t idx = random() % DECK_SIZE;
    printf("(%i, %s), ", cards[idx].rank, suit_name[cards[idx].suit]);
    idx = random() % DECK_SIZE;
    printf("(%i, %s)\n", cards[idx].rank, suit_name[cards[idx].suit]);

    return 0;
}

function drawCards(number) {
    return [...Array(number)].map((_) => {
        let n = Math.random();
        let number = ((n * 13) | 0) + 1;
        let symbol = n > 0.75 ? '' : n > 0.5 ? '' : n > 0.25 ? '' : '';
        let formatedNumber =
            number == 1
                ? 'A'
                : number == 11
                ? 'J'
                : number == 12
                ? 'Q'
                : number == 13
                ? 'K'
                : number;

        return formatedNumber + symbol;
    });
}

package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "math/rand"
    "strconv"
    "time"
)

type Suit int

const (
    Spades Suit = iota
    Clubs
    Hearts
    Diamonds
)

func (s Suit) String() string {
    switch s {
    case Spades:
        return "Spades"
    case Clubs:
        return "Clubs"
    case Hearts:
        return "Hearts"
    case Diamonds:
        return "Diamonds"
    default:
        panic("unknown suit")
    }
}

type Value int

const (
    Ace Value = iota
    Two
    Three
    Four
    Five
    Six
    Seven
    Eight
    Nine
    Ten
    Jack
    Queen
    King
)

func (v Value) String() string {
    switch v {
    case Ace:
        return "Ace"
    case Jack:
        return "Jack"
    case Queen:
        return "Queen"
    case King:
        return "King"
    default:
        return strconv.Itoa(int(v))
    }
}

type Card struct {
    Suit  Suit
    Value Value
}

type Deck []Card

func (c Card) String() string {
    return fmt.Sprintf("%v of %v", c.Value, c.Suit)
}

func main() {
    // Create Deck
    deck := Deck{}
    for i := Spades; i <= Diamonds; i++ {
        for j := Ace; j <= King; j++ {
            deck = append(
                deck,
                Card{Suit: i, Value: j})
        }
    }
    // Shuffle Deck
    // Uncomment to make shuffling non-deterministic
    // rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
    rand.Shuffle(len(deck), func(i, j int) {
        deck[i], deck[j] = deck[j], deck[i]
    })
    // Draw
    card1, card2 := deck[rand.Intn(len(deck))],
        deck[rand.Intn(len(deck))]
    fmt.Printf("Card 1: %v\nCard 2: %v\n", card1, card2)
}

#!/bin/guile -s
!#

(define (range n)
  (if (= n 0) '()
      (cons n (range (- n 1)))))

(define (replicate l n)
  (if (= 0 n) '()
      (append l (replicate l (- n 1)))))

(define (conseach a l)
  (if (null? l) '()
      (cons (cons a (car l)) (conseach a (cdr l)))))

(define (product xs ys)
  (if (null? xs) '()
      (append (conseach (car xs) ys) (product (cdr xs) ys))))
 
(define (list-ref lst n)
  (if (= 0 n)
      (car lst)
      (list-ref (cdr lst) (- n 1))))

(define (remove l n)
  (if (= n 0) (cdr l)
      (cons (car l) (remove (cdr l) (- n 1)))))

(define (takerand l)
  (let ((r (random (length l))))
    (and (display (list-ref l r)) (newline) (remove l r))))

(set! *random-state* (random-state-from-platform))
(takerand (takerand (product '(hearts clubs spades diamonds) (replicate (range 12) 4))))

posts.com:
>>91255008
>>91261028
It *does* drop off bits. It truncates the number.
When you do 'OR 0', it's equivalent to 'OR 0xFFFFFFFF'. This means, any number that is represented as 0x80000000 (2147483648) or greater will return as a negative number.
Math.floor rounds down, bitwise operations round up.
// Safe
 (2147483647.5918 & 0xFFFFFFFF) ===  2147483647
 (2147483647      & 0xFFFFFFFF) ===  2147483647
 (200.59082098    & 0xFFFFFFFF) ===  200
 (0X7FFFFFFF      & 0xFFFFFFFF) ===  0X7FFFFFFF
 
 // Unsafe
 (2147483648      & 0xFFFFFFFF) === -2147483648
 (-2147483649     & 0xFFFFFFFF) ===  2147483647
 (0x80000000      & 0xFFFFFFFF) === -2147483648
 (3000000000.5    & 0xFFFFFFFF) === -1294967296

Really, the correct thing is to use Math.trunc instead, since bitwise operations may behave differently due to platform changes

function shuffle(deck) {
  let middle = deck.length / 2
  let shuffledCards = []
  
  for (let i = 0; i < middle; i++) {
    shuffledCards.push(deck[i])
    shuffledCards.push(deck[middle + i])
  }

  return shuffledCards
}

function getRandPos(len) {
  return Math.floor(Math.random() * (len - 1))
}

const DECK_SIZE = 52
let deck = []

for (let i = 0; i < DECK_SIZE; i++) deck.push(i + 1)
for (let i = 0; i < 6; i++) deck = shuffle(deck)

let card1 = deck[getRandPos(DECK_SIZE)]
let card2 = deck[getRandPos(DECK_SIZE)]

console.log(`${card1}, ${card2}`)

>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source: lacks a headphone jack, has high noise/distortion (common on PC), or lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy FiiO/CCA/KZ?
No. Despite their previous popularity, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio

Guide to IEMs:
https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu
*WIP New Guide to IEMs:
https://rentry.org/c8gqc

i think it goes back to processor chips becoming rarer/more expensive. hard to make a complete audiofool-approved audio quality device + all the connectivity (USB/BT/audio out/in) + screen + all the misc functions for cheap price. to meet lower price, the manufacturer has to nerf CPU, battery, or some other internals

Less lag is why I started buying non-tws. Then I checked graphs and figured I could get more bass and started exploring. Found out graphs won't tell you how good the bass is and they also can't tell you if an IEM EQ's well or not. Then I found out you can have good sub-bass on an IEM but also have shit mid-bass, Crossover issues, or bleeding issues. Or you can find some good bass and then shit treble. Then you're listening to reviewers who swear they can hear Beethoven let out a silent fart with their $2000 IEM's and other details they've never heard before.

It's really a pain in the ass but it does pay off if you really try. I'm using the kiiboom allure's right now which EQ very well. Just tried out the Final e5000's which have some bass but it's not tight and adding more through EQ barely does anything. Tried the Finals because the kiiboom's stick into the cartiladge in my ear which causes discomfort after some time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91237495
>would it even be worth it to buy them in that case?
You determine the worth when you hear them. You're already jumping into the realm of diminishing returns. You have a pair of IEMs that sound perfectly fine, especially with EQ. Will spending 15x the money get you 15x the sound performance? Nowhere close, no. If we can even quantify the difference in numbers, is it maybe 10, 15... 25% better? Again, up to you in the end. Without being too repetitive, this anon speaks about some realities of IEMs that I agree with >>91234350 mainly that a graph can tell you the approximate sound/volume an IEM makes, but not necessarily the "quality" of the sound in specific portions of the frequency response. The "quality" of sound will likely be better in the more expensive 1DD, but it's not guaranteed

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91257815
Lightning port is 5 Volts DC
The Sundara requires needs 1W minimally to drive it. So that would mean 200mA of power. These are 38 impedance headphones so you'd need about 132mA to drive them.

So the dongle will be able to drive them, but because these are planar, don't expect them to fully give you the expected sound, especially with low frequencies where they'll need more power to slam those heavy notes.

Joshua/That guy seems to drive them but he also says not to expect the audio quality of a dedicated DAC. But he's just a YouTube reviewer selling headphones. That dongle is meant to drive smaller earplugs, not full sized planar headphones. So also expect your battery to drain faster.

Anyway, just buy the dongle, it's cheap. If that doesn't work, buy a cheap but good DAC to plug it in the dongle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Why is it that all "alternative" OSes just turn out to be different flavors of UNIX? I understand the desirability of targeting a POSIX userland since it limits the necessary scope of the OS and prevents systems devs from having to write a ton of random applications to make their OS useful, but it all just seems so pointless when there's so many already functional alternatives that do exactly the same thing.

If we forgot everything we know about Windows, about UNIX and UNIX-likes, about every OS currently in existence, and decided to design a system to interconnect all of our hardware, peripherals, and network devices in a way that prioritizes speed, security, reliability, and portability, what would that system look like? Would it still be some manner of UNIX-like because that's the true optimal way to do everything? Or would we end up with something completely different if we weren't shackled to 50 years of legacy cruft?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91236837
>Why is it that all "alternative" OSes just turn out to be different flavors of UNIX?
you basically answered the question 100%
posix is a reasonably well defined public standard that means you don't need to reinvent the wheel for software, that's it
if there was another well defined public standard, you'd probably see some alt-OSes implementing it (or hell, even see implementations of it in Linux distros)

>Would it still be some manner of UNIX-like because that's the true optimal way to do everything?
I genuinely doubt it -- in particular, the idea that the fork/exec model of process creation would happen again is something I'd consider extremely unlikely, along with a lot of other *nix-isms
maybe ideas like "everything as a file" might reappear, if in greater or lesser proportion vs a typical *nix system of today
a lot of Unix's text-orientation probably wouldn't develop in a world focused so much more on multimedia... although, maybe it would, since all the efforts of having some kind of well-defined object-based system for interfaces and files in an OS died out in favor of how dead simple just being like "here's a text file" is

My complaint isn't so much with POSIX as with the fact that everything in between hardware and POSIX always seems to turn out the same. Whether we're talking about Linux or Solaris or Darwin or the BSDs or Plan 9 or Serenity, they're all more or less the same under the hood (maybe a bit "less" in the case of Plan 9, but not so much as /g/ seems to think). There's nothing anymore (that I'm aware of, at least) that challenges the very concept of what an OS is, like Nemesis or Amoeba.

>in particular, the idea that the fork/exec model of process creation would happen again is something I'd consider extremely unlikely
This is an interesting example of a thing that I guess I'm just too familiar with and wouldn't even consider as a candidate for replacement. What alternatives exist and how might they contribute to speed, security, capability, or reliability?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91238658
>My complaint isn't so much with POSIX as with the fact that everything in between hardware and POSIX always seems to turn out the same.
People go with what works. Hell, I can't even say that >>91224953 is wrong, there really has been fuck all research in decades. I think MS was fucking around with that Singularity thing that was supposed to be their big all-managed CLR operating system, and that was more than 10 years ago now.
Anything particularly out-there doesn't get traction.

>This is an interesting example of a thing that I guess I'm just too familiar with and wouldn't even consider as a candidate for replacement. What alternatives exist and how might they contribute to speed, security, capability, or reliability?
Some variation of direct process spawning would probably be more likely, with probably a second command by the main process to actually start the child once you've actually set things up (eg, all the things you'd typically do between fork() and exec()).
This simplifies the semantics by not having to make a copy of the current process (and yeah, copy-on-write and all of that). It's absurdly rare that I do want a copy of the current program, I am almost always just starting another one entirely

although, I think I'm still looking at this from a fork/exec perspective
and you'd probably just see a single spawn() function that just returns a process ID and takes the path of the program to run
which is typical for systems that don't have POSIX influence

you could read
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/uploads/prod/2019/04/fork-hotos19.pdf
for some examples of why people don't like fork/exec, although I'm not entirely sold against the model, and it IS from an MS source (and MS uses a CreateProcess function in Windows)

>>91247254
I skipped the boot sector. There is a bootloader called limine which seems to be adequate.
>>91248317
>How will it differ from other OS?
Mostly by being created by me and not someone else. I am following the description written in "Unix System V Release 4: The Complete Reference" mostly, and only breaking from it to implement some newer things (like slab allocation), some ideas from other OSs (like Linux epoll, Windows asynchronous procedure calls), and with drivers (I am writing those in sepples.)
Difference from other hobby kernels specifically is that I am trying to be true to the actual feature set of Unix SVR4. That means I need virtual memory with memory mapping, swapping and a page cache, I need support for networking including a network filesystem, I need dynamic linking, and I need priority-based scheduling. If I can do half of the features on that list, it would be a big improvement on almost all hobby kernels.

>>91245841
I'm starting my own, although I doubt it will ever become useful, much less be completed, since the scope is unreasonably large. Current stage is doing research to try to define exactly how large that scope is. My goal is a tinfoil hat OS that is 100% glownigger proof, which means that not only am I operating on the very lowest levels of hardware (to ensure it can't be rootkitted, it will have to extend all the way down to the bootloader and BIOS), it will have to implement encryption everywhere as soon as possible (possibly even down to the shared L3 cache), and have to protect against obscure side channel attacks like differential power analysis.

On the other end of things, I'd be happy in the short term to be able to initialize RAM and an NVMe drive, interface with basic USB input devices, and display a framebuffer. Ultimately, I think the endgame would be taking a screenshot and posting it to /g/, but that's so far out I don't really want to think about it.

I'm such a retard, I tell myself : "only change 1 variable" and I go ahead and change two so I'm not too confident with some of my assumptions. Also it's worth mentioning for those who don't know if you want to get the same exact results as before we had to set the network alpha value, all you have to do is set network alpha equal to the network dim value you were using and everything works the same as before except you won't get the webui throwing a missing key error.

>>91262021
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX. Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called “Linux,” and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project. There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use.

Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called “Linux” distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

>>91265263
I already fixed the EOS token yesterday with an experimental fix. However our users do NOT normally want eos tokens because it goes against what people normally use Kobold for. People normally use Kobold AI for story generation so they want to be able to generate larger portions of text without the model cutting it off.

That means the default behavior will not change, it is up to the pygmalion developers to include the setting to unblock EOS in the config of their model. When they do, the fix of the EOS tokens should activate and hopefully work properly (Haven't tested the TPU yet because of another bug I am fixing on the TPU side, on the GPU side it works as intended).

So in our case its not a bug but a feature, and a feature models can turn off if needed trough a setting in their config.

>>91252381
"Severely constrained" rather than "badly designed". The machine the first C compiler was developed on had 8k 18-bit words (i.e. 18kB in today's terms) that had to be shared by both the OS and the compiler.

Originally, you had to declare all external variables and functions you wanted to use *in that function*. Here's code by Ritchie himself:

function() {
    extern declare, blkhed, blkend;
    extern printf, statement, peeksym, cval, symbol, retseq;
    extern paraml;
    auto o;

    printf(".text; 1:mov r5,-(sp); mov sp,r5\n");
    declare(8);
    declist();
    statement(1);
    retseq();
}


As computers got beefier, you could keep track of not just identifiers for the current function, but for an entire file at a time! Some genius thought to share small snippets from each file as a header allowing multiple source units to share definitions without the insane madman's ramblings of trying to keep track of *multiple* source files at the time, which would only be feasible with the computing budget of a significant country.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91260006
While true, it is a serious and chronic management problem in devops. People buy into all these enterprise solutions for everything instead of doing a serious assessment of needs and problems. So shit that is actually one of the most important operational elements (secrets management) gets left as an afterthought or side feature.

I have found docker compose to be pure cancer for this general category. People spooge all over their screen when they see it only takes 5 minutes to deploy something as complex as gitlab while ignoring the fact that what they just deployed is an operational heap of rotting garbage. The same thing happened with AWS marketplace when that first got big. Just rent this image from us and you can be up and running in 2 minutes! Cue months of pain later on if nobody is smart enough to stop that shit from moving to production without at least a sanity check.
